title: A Novel Approach to Define the Peak Hours of Consumption for Individual Customers and Groups of Customers Using Functional Data Analysis
text:
The work should be visible below. If it isn’t please clink this (link).

Abstract
The following text was obtained from the publication.

A common analysis in utilities is the use of meter read data to define peak hours of consumption. This paper proposes a novel approach using functional data analysis (FDA) to define the peak hours of consumption for individual customers and groups of customers. Through functional data analysis, smooth, differentiable curves are fitted to an individual customer’s meter read data. Then, the individual on-peak times are aggregated to define on-peak hours for a group of customers, such as for all residential customers.


The individual customer on-peak hours are proposed as the times of day where the velocity or the rate of change is greatest or least, respectively. The group on-peak hours are determined by two different methods; the first by assessing the distributions of the start and end aggregated individual on-peak windows and the second via an unsupervised statistical learning procedure.

title: Functional Features for Time Series
text:
About
This work is exploratory and currently unfinished. The purpose of the work is to assess if features created using functional data analysis are useful. The work was inspired by Catch22.
As far as I am aware, this is novel research.
The following is a description from the Catch22 GitHub repo:

Catch22 is a collection of 22 time-series features coded in C that can be run from Python, R, Matlab, and Julia. The catch22 features are a high-performing subset of the over 7000 features in hctsa



Details
I’ve been working and learning about functional data analysis on and off for the past three years. Over the course of this time I learned about Catch22 and other works(hctsa, theft, feast).
Much of my work focused on analyzing energy consumption data. During this time I learned that the deriatives of energy consumption were helpful to gain a more complete understanding of consumption patterns. The derivatives are velocity and accelartion.
With functional data analysis it’s trivial to estimate the velocity and accerlation of a smooth curve fitted to the data. I thought that summarizing these derivatives into features would be helpful/ predictive.


Analysis
The first step is to evaluate if the functional features are significant. I will attempt to assess this by comparing the functional features agains features from existing libraries. This is a link to the code.
If the funcitonal features are found to be predictive, then a subsequent step would be to produce a package so others can test the features for themselves.
Progress:

step 1: evaluation of functional features: work in progress
step 2: create a package
